componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to the Newmont Mining Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Today's conference is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the call over to Meredith Bandy, Vice President, Investor Relations, you may begin.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to Newmont's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Joining us on the call today are Gary Goldberg, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Laurie Brlas, Chief Financial Officer. They and other members of o
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning, everyone, and welcome to Newmont's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Joining us on the call today are Gary Goldberg, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Laurie Brlas, Chief Financial Officer. They and other members of our executive team will be available to answer questions at the end of the call. 
Turning to Slide 2, before I go any further, please take a moment to review the cautionary statement shown here or refer to our SEC filings, which can be found on our website at newmont.com. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Gary.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Meredith, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to report that Newmont delivered another strong quarter and I appreciate the opportunity to walk you through details now. Our operations continued to drive cause down, work more safely and increase
componenttext:
Thanks, Meredith, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to report that Newmont delivered another strong quarter and I appreciate the opportunity to walk you through details now. Our operations continued to drive cause down, work more safely and increased gold and copper production compared to the prior-year quarter. This performance helped us double our operating cash flow, significantly improve adjusted EBITDA and deliver a 9-fold increase in free cash flow compared to last year, despite lower metal prices.
Our portfolio is also stronger than it was a year ago. We executed value accretive transactions and remain on track with our 4 development projects in the Americas. We also announced the decision to proceed with our Tanami Expansion project in Australia. Finally, we strengthened our balance sheet, made our commitment to pay dividends and repaid $50 million of debt. 
I'll turn to Slide 4 for a moment on these achievements. We continue to execute the 3 elements of our strategy: First, we improved our underlying business by lowering injury rates 15%, decreasing all-in sustaining costs 16%, and increasing gold production 16% quarter-on-quarter. We also tripled copper production. Second, we strengthened our portfolio by acquiring Cripple Creek & Victor as selling assets that represent lower value or higher risk to Newmont.
We remain on schedule and on or under budget at Turf Vent Shaft, Merian and Long Canyon Phase 1. We're also moving forward with our Tanami Expansion project, an investment that will increase profitable production and extend mine life at very competitive returns. 
Finally, we created shareholder value by generating $758 million in adjusted EBITDA and $478 million in free cash flow during the third quarter. This allowed us to continue to sell fund our best projects, pay dividends and pay down debt. Delevering our strategy starts at the mine phase. 
Turning to Slide 5. I visited her team earlier this month and was impressed with our newest operations performance. The team recently reached one-year working with 0 harm and is delivering exceptional business results. This is the bar we're sitting for all our operations. Overall, our total injury rates were 15% lower than the prior year quarter and remained among the lowest in the mining industry. This performance is overshadowed, however, by the loss of a contractor, working on a tree cutting team in Indonesia. Teddy was stuck in upper body by a falling tree and recently succumbed to his injuries. Our thoughts are with his family and his colleagues. Our work to make our operations safer and more efficient never ends. 
Turning to our cost performance on Slide 6. Our gold all-in sustaining costs were $835 per ounce, bringing our year-to-date cost to $864 per ounce. This represents a 27% reduction since 2012. About half the improvements we achieved in the third quarter as a result of sustainable cost and efficiency improvements across the portfolio and higher productivity and sales at low-cost operations. We also benefited from favorable oil price and exchange rates and some delayed timing in our capital expenditures. 
Turning to production on Slide 7. We produced more than 1.3 million attributable ounces of gold during the third quarter. This constitutes 16% more than the prior year quarter and our highest output in the last 7 quarters. New production from CC&V offset about 2/3 of the reductions associated with divestments. We also produced 48,000 tons of copper, mostly as a result of higher grades at Batu Hijau. Our Highway 4 operation that drove this performance. At Batu Hijau, third quarter production reflected higher ore grades, which will mine through 2017. At Boddington, mine plan and full potential improvements unlock higher grades and increase new utilization and recoveries. Tanami delivered strong production and on back of higher grade and improved productivity and also mill utilization, which were achieved through full potential. And finally, Twin Creeks, benefited from improved mill grades and the completion of plan stripping campaign. Putting it all together, our operations are doing good work to maximize opportunities and mitigate challenges. 
Turning to Slide 8. In North America, the Turf Vent Shaft remains unscheduled to reach commercial production in the fourth quarter and will be completed below budget. Engineering and mine development also remain on track at Long Canyon, where we continue to expect first production in 2017. You can see the Leach pad and other surface facilities in this photo. The CC&V integration is also progressing and the operation celebrated 5 million ounces of gold produced last month. Ramp up to full mill capacity slightly behind schedule, and we have adjusted our outlook accordingly. We're working out the bugs and the delay is not expected to impact longer-term production. 
Turning to South America. Merian remains on budget and on schedule to begin producing in 2016. Construction is just over 40% complete and we've stockpiled more than 930,000 tons of ore at higher than planned grades. We're also advancing Project Integral, a phased approach to developing remaining oxide and sulfur deposits and we will have a initial findings by mid 2016. In Africa, we're now operating at full capacity on grid power and new generations generators will be commissioned by year end. We're also advancing our broader power strategy to secure reliable and affordable supply over the long term.
In Indonesia, we expect our export to be renewed in near future and continue to work with the government to finalize amendments to our contract at work. In the meantime, we're operating in full capacity and storing concentrate or shipping it to for processing. In Australia, we've announced that we're moving forward with the Tanami Expansion project. 
Turning to Slide 9, since 2012, Tanami has more than doubled its gold production, cutting costs by about 2/3 and significantly improving resource confidence. The Tanami expansion project builds on this trajectory. It involves constructing a second decline in the underground mine and incremental capacity in the plant to increase profitable production and extend the mine life. The project is the outcome of a detailed review of options to maximize near-term cash flow and long-term asset value.
In the first 5 years of full production, the expansion will increase Tanami's average annual gold production by 80,000 ounces, while all-in sustaining costs by between 5% and 10% and extend mine life by 3 years. First production is expected in the second half of 2017. Adding a second decline will also serve as a platform for exploration drilling to support future expansions. As I mentioned last quarter, we see the potential to double current reserves and resources at comparable grades, by expanding the and Auron deposits and developing new discoveries at Federation and Liberator. We're excited about this project and what the team has done to optimize it. For investment between $100 million and $120 million, the project provides a return of more than 35%, at $1,100 gold and more than 25% at gold prices as low as $900 per ounce. 
With that, I will hand it over to Lori for an update on our financial results.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to report that Newmont delivered a great quarter with solid financial results. Turning to slide 11. As Gary mentioned, we continue to see cost improvement across the portfolio. Our third quarter gold
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to report that Newmont delivered a great quarter with solid financial results. 
Turning to slide 11. As Gary mentioned, we continue to see cost improvement across the portfolio. Our third quarter gold cost applicable to sales per ounce and gold all-in sustaining costs per ounce were 14% and 16% favorable respectively, to the prior-year quarter. With these most recent results, we have maintained our portfolio all-in sustaining costs below $1,000 per ounce for the last 5 quarters running. Gold production was also strong in the quarter and was up 16% from the prior year.
Despite a 13% decline in the average realized gold price from a year ago, we continue to generate strong earnings and robust cash flow. 
Turning to slide 12, during the third quarter, revenue was up 16% and we generated $813 million in cash from continuing operations, an increase of more than 148% from the year-ago quarter. Adjusted EBITDA was up 67% from the prior year, due to higher production at Batu Hijau, Boddington, Tanami and Twin Creeks, improved oil prices and exchange rates and ongoing cost and efficiency improvements. Consolidated free cash flow was $478 million during the third quarter as higher sales volumes and improved cost offset increased development capital spending at Merian and Long Canyon Phase 1. With these most recent results, our year-to-date free cash flow has grown to $941 million, an amount roughly 8x more than what was generated a year ago. We reported adjusted net income of $126 million in the third quarter or $0.23 per share compared to $249 million or $0.50 per share last year. 
Turning to slide 13. We walked through the adjusted net income adjustments, which include a $0.04 per share gain related to discontinued operations, a $0.10 per share gain related to the TMAC deconsolidation. In the past, we fully consolidated TMAC, but upon completion of their IPO, that is no longer required for accounting purposes. The results will not be included in our line-by-line numbers going forward, and instead will be captured in our equity income line. This gain was on the actual event of deconsolidation and we carved it out for purposes of adjusted net income. It also gave rise to a $0.05 per share gain, resulting from an adjustment to our tax valuation allowances. 
In the quarter, we also recognized $0.07 per share gain on asset sales, primarily our stake in Valcambi refinery. For adjusted net income purposes, we also carved out of $0.04 per share loss related to impairments and loss provisions, and a $0.03 per share loss is related to restructuring, acquisition cost and other minor items.
After reconciling for these items, we reported adjusted net income of $126 million or $0.23 per share. We're particularly pleased to note that this number includes $0.02 of accretion from the addition of to our portfolio for just 2 months. A similar outcome is seen in adjusted EBITDA of $758 million, up 67% from the prior year. It is adjusted for essentially the same unusual items. 
Now turning to slide 14. A strong balance sheet provides a competitive advantage in a volatile gold environment and we continue to execute on capital priorities designed to safeguard our investment grade ratings. At the end of the third quarter, our balance sheet had roughly $3 million in cash and cash equivalents in addition, we have about $400 million in marketable securities, and a $3 billion revolver that is essentially undrawn. In total, that's $6.4 billion of liquidity. This and our strong cash flow in 2015 gives us the comfort that we can start and finish our projects without having to take on additional debt to fund that. 
During the third quarter, we repaid $50 million of that towards the revolver. This brings our year-to-date total debt payment $330 million. We expect to pay down further debt later this year and are on track to repaid a total of $750 million by year end. As always, further payments will be made in context of the current business and market environment, but our significant cash balance certainly supports our ability to pay off additional debt. Given our existing cash balances and revolver, we have ample flexibility to execute on our capital priorities and are actively monitoring the gold price and the fixed income market to evaluate our options. We also maintained our dividend in light of our strong cash flow and operating performance. As a reminder, we have no significant debt maturities due until 2019, and our current net debt to book capital of 19% is well below the maximum 62.5% covenant on our revolver, which is our only covenant. 
And now, turning to slide 15. We are proud that our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of roughly 1.1% is among the lowest in the industry and has continued to improve. We have transformed Newmont's balance sheet into one of the strongest in sector and our liquidity and cash flow generation separate us from the competition. We have reduced our net debt by 32% from the prior year quarter. And more importantly, we have reduced net debt, while also growing our EBITDA, which significantly improves our financial flexibility. We remain comfortable with our relative level of debt and maturity profile and we will continue to examine ways to reduce the absolute debt level and increased the long-term strength of our business. 
And now, I will turn the call back over to Gary.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Laurie. I'll shift gears now to look at the future. Turning to slide 17. We expect to end 2015 with attributable gold production at the higher end of our guidance range, which is between 4.7 million and 5.1 million ounces and copper products of
componenttext:
Thanks, Laurie. I'll shift gears now to look at the future. 
Turning to slide 17. We expect to end 2015 with attributable gold production at the higher end of our guidance range, which is between 4.7 million and 5.1 million ounces and copper products of between 140,000 tons in 180,000 tons. The changes we're making to our 2015 guidance are twofold. First, we are lowering our outlook for gold all-in sustaining costs 4% between $880 and $940. This reflects strong performance, particularly in Asia Pacific and Africa, as well as lower exchange rates in favorable power and diesel prices. We expect these cost to rise slightly in the fourth quarter due to higher exploration and advanced project spending, sustaining capital timing and lower grades at Yanacocha. Second we lowered our full year outlook for capital expenditures by about 9%, between $1.4 billion to $1.6 billion. This reduction reflects lower sustaining capital expenditures of between $740 million and $780 million or 13% below previous guidance. Again, cost efficiency improvements at Yanacocha, Boddington, Batu Hijau, Ahafo Akyem as well as some timing impacts. Our improved outlook also deflects lower development capital, including $50 million in savings at Merian, realized through supply-chain improvements, favorable exchange rates and lower commodity prices. This reduction is partially offset by new development capital for the Tanami Expansion project. Our project pipeline continues to be one of the strongest in the gold sector. 
Turning to slide 18. Our projects focus on profitably extending the life of our existing operations, we are to opening perspective new mining districts. Before we reach funding decisions, we scrutinize our approach to each project with a goal to lower initial capital cost, accelerate payback and leverage existing infrastructure. Projects that are in the execution phase include that Turf Vent Shaft, which will give us access to be between 100,000 and 150,000 ounces of higher grade ore per year and support for the expansion at Leeville. Merian, which will deliver 400,000 to 500,000 ounces of gold at all-in sustaining costs of between $650 to $750 per ounce for the first 5 years beginning in 2016.
The Cripple Creek & Victor expansion, which includes the New mill, leach pad and recovery plant that will be commissioned in second half of 2016. CC&V will contribute between 350,000 and 400,000 ounces of gold in 2016 and 2017 and is expected to lower Newmont's overall cost profile. The first phase of Long Canyon, which will add between 100,000 ounces of gold and 150,000 ounces of gold per year at all-in sustaining costs of between $500 and $600 per ounce beginning in 2017. And finally, the Tanami Expansion project, which I touched on earlier. Further up the pipeline, we're advancing the Ahafo Mill Expansion in Subika underground mine in Ghana. These projects are design to help offset the impact of lower grades and harder we have deferred the decision to proceed with the Ahafo Mill Expansion until the second half of next year to coincide with our timing on the Subika Underground decision.
We're also progressing the phase 7 cutback at Batu Hijau, where we are working to secure the stability we need for ongoing investment. Quecher Main, which is part of the oxide expansion effort in Yanacocha. And Northwest Exodus in Nevada, which would extend the current underground operation and add profitable production. 
Turning to exploration on slide 19. Exploration is one of our core competencies. About 70% of the Board their mining in 2015 was discovered by Newmont geologists. Our program focuses on maintaining our existing resource base, while preserving options to pursue significant new discoveries. We employ rigorous standards to make sure the highest-quality ounces are added to our reserve base and we've developed proprietary geologic risk assessment project to improve our orebody confidence. This map shows prospects in Nevada, Peru, Ghana and Australia that we expect to be in production before 2020. And longer term prospects in the U.S., Ethiopia and the Guiana Shield.
Turning to slide 20 for a closer look at our underground prospects that Exodus in Nevada. Exodus is a high-grade underground old body that was identified in 2008 with 300,000 ounce discovery. Through new discoveries at Northwest Exodus in 2011 and Exodus Footwall in 2013, we've grown the resource base to 1.2 million ounces to date, of which 300,000 ounces have been mined. We see the potential to double this figure over the next few years by converting mineral inventory into reserves and resource, and by drilling the remaining half of Exodus' targeted mineralization. 
Turning to slide 21. Northwest Exodus is located several hundred meters from Exodus. We declared a main resource of 700,000 ounces in 2014, and expect to declare first results in early 2016. Compared to our initial Exodus discovery, Northwest Exodus is larger with 50% higher grades, mineralization remains open on the hanging wall.
Turning to slide 22. the exodus Footwall is our latest discovery and is located in different stratigraphy than Exodus in Northwest Exodus. We recently identified mineralization of upto 51 meters at grades of 12.5 grams ton and the footwall remains open along strike and at depth. We anticipate declaring first resource at Exodus Footwall in early 2016. While we intend to pursue these opportunities, we're also prepared for a ongoing market volatility. 
Turning to slide 23. At today's metal prices, we can afford to advance our best projects and exploration projects, fund our dividends and repay debt. This chart gives you an idea of what maybe might do differently in a prolonged period of lower or higher gold prices. Under significant constraints, we would delay stepping campaigns and sustain capital, we complete our current projects and further reduce overhead and exploration cost. As gold price improves, we will continue to optimize cost in capital, fund our most profitable projects, accelerate debt repayment and increase dividend in line with our policy. Getting our house in order now allows us to deliver superior margins when gold price recovers. 
Turning to slide 24. We're continuing to make good progress toward our goal to become the world's most profitable and reliable gold producer. We will reach that goal by continuing to deliver our strategy to improve our underlying business, by continuously raising our safety, cost and technical performance to strengthen our portfolio by building a longer life, lower-cost asset base and to create shareholder value by generating cash, paying dividends and strengthening our investment grade balance sheet. Thank you for your time. 
I'd like to open the floor for questions now. Operator?

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. I suppose you are saying obviously the benefits and tailwinds from the Aussie dollars and oil price are falling. Can you just give us some comments on how would you think about going forward with hedging and would you increase
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. I suppose you are saying obviously the benefits and tailwinds from the Aussie dollars and oil price are falling. Can you just give us some comments on how would you think about going forward with hedging and would you increase your hedging exposure on the cost side?

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Andrew. Historically, we've had foreign exchange hedges in place in Australia and a little bit New Zealand, first New Zealand, is gone away. In Australia, we liquidated about 2/3 of our position back in about 2 years ago, it's been November of 2013
componenttext: Sure, Andrew. Historically, we've had foreign exchange hedges in place in Australia and a little bit New Zealand, first New Zealand, is gone away. In Australia, we liquidated about 2/3 of our position back in about 2 years ago, it's been November of 2013 and we're continuing to draw that down, it runs down basically, it's pretty small now and over the next 2 to 3 years, it's gone, but it's very small portion. We don't see ourselves changing that hedge position or increasing it quite frankly. We've seen a good correlation between gold price and the Aussie dollars, not really that drives anything, but we don't see any need to make a change in our position on the foreign exchange rate hedging. When it comes to the diesel fuel, we basically do that in Nevada, because of the ability for us to take hedge accounting and we're not taking a position on where the price will go. It's just we do it in order to smooth out what the orders things might be. So we got basically an evergreen time hedge book arrangement there that we continue out to 2 to 2.5 year period to cover that. But we're not taking any strong positions on price there either.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the way we're looking at it, we need to clearly get the export permit and we expect that here in the next week or 2 in terms of getting that. So we continue to mine through phase 6 and that's just been part of the process every 6 months of re
componenttext: Yes. I think the way we're looking at it, we need to clearly get the export permit and we expect that here in the next week or 2 in terms of getting that. So we continue to mine through phase 6 and that's just been part of the process every 6 months of renewing that. In terms of the contract to work, we do need to get those changes done now. We agreed those changes should get a year ago with MoU with the government and really need to get that finalized and get the certainty of that as well as get the financing in place like we did in the phase 6, get the financing in place to support phase 7. So I would expect and the way we're looking at it, we have got over the next year to get that in place and that's the timeframe that we're looking at.

componenttextpreview: Thanks for the question, John. We'll give a detailed update on that in February, when we do the update on reserves and resources at year end. But we have given previous sensitivities out there on what it looks like at say $100 lower reserve price. We are
componenttext: Thanks for the question, John. We'll give a detailed update on that in February, when we do the update on reserves and resources at year end. But we have given previous sensitivities out there on what it looks like at say $100 lower reserve price. We are using currently 3,000 per reserves, and a 1,200. Right now I would expect we'd probably move to 1,200, but I don't expect this to see as biggest swing on the reserves as what we have shown in that sensitivity. Really 2 things helping that, one, has been how we got our cost down throughout the organization and that helps make things economic at lower prices. The other piece has been the swing in the Aussie dollars, where would where we would have seen impact at Boddington, I wouldn't expect that we would see that but we will give you details when we'll come out with the reserve and results numbers beginning of next year.

componenttext: Brian, we're not really connected to Freeport on export permit. There's a different condition than ours. componenttext: I think, Brian, there is a couple of things that -- first off, they're working through some design issues that we're confident that we can't solve by taking more time. So ramp up of the actual equipment has taken a bit longer than we would have expected. I think the other aspect of it is around portending, making some changes around how we mine and feed the plant that we're addressing to get more throughput and maximize the grade through the plant as it was designed for. And I think the third piece that maybe address the question longer-term is, we're looking at how to reconfigure that plant the opportunity to take the concentrate, rather than leaching it there and the complexities that brings within the plant, taking that concentrate in Nevada and putting it in either our autoclaves at doing or our roaster at Carlin, which is an advantage for both CC&V and absolutely the 2 Nevada operations.

componenttext: Thanks, again, for joining our third quarter earnings call this morning. headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Newmont's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Joining us on the call today are Gary Goldberg, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Laurie Brlas, Chief Financial Officer. They and other member
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to Newmont's Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. Joining us on the call today are Gary Goldberg, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Laurie Brlas, Chief Financial Officer. They and other members of our executive team will be available to answer questions at the end of the call. 
Turning to Slide 2, before I go any further, please take a moment to review the cautionary statement shown here or refer to our SEC filings, which can be found on our website at newmont.com. 
With that, I'll turn it over to Gary.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Meredith, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to report that Newmont delivered another strong quarter, and I appreciate the opportunity to walk you through details now. Our operations continued to drive cost down, work more safely and increase
componenttext:
Thanks, Meredith, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to report that Newmont delivered another strong quarter, and I appreciate the opportunity to walk you through details now. Our operations continued to drive cost down, work more safely and increase gold and copper production compared to the prior year quarter. This performance helped us double our operating cash flow, significantly improve adjusted EBITDA and deliver a 9-fold increase in free cash flow compared to last year, despite lower metal prices.
Our portfolio is also stronger than it was a year ago. We executed value accretive transactions, and remained on track with our 4 development projects in the Americas. We also announced the decision to proceed with our Tanami Expansion project in Australia. Finally, we strengthened our balance sheet, met our commitment to pay dividends and repaid $50 million of debt. 
I'll turn to Slide 4 for a moment on these achievements. We continue to execute the 3 elements of our strategy. First, we improved our underlying business by lowering injury rates 15%, decreasing all-in sustaining costs 16% and increasing gold production 16% quarter-on-quarter. We also tripled copper production.
Second, we strengthened our portfolio by acquiring Cripple Creek & Victor and selling assets that represent lower value or higher risk to Newmont. We remain on schedule and on or under budget at Turf Vent Shaft, Merian and Long Canyon Phase 1. We're also moving forward with our Tanami Expansion project, an investment that will increase profitable production and extend mine life at very competitive returns. 
Finally, we created shareholder value by generating $758 million in adjusted EBITDA and $478 million in free cash flow during the third quarter. This allowed us to continue to sell fund our best projects, pay dividends and pay down debt.
Delevering our strategy starts at the mine phase. Turning to Slide 5. I visited the team earlier this month and was impressed with our newest operations performance. The team recently reached 1 year working with 0 harm, and is delivering exceptional business results. This is the bar we're setting for all our operations.
Overall, our total injury rates were 15% lower than the prior year quarter and remained among the lowest in the mining industry. This performance is overshadowed, however, by the loss of a contractor working on a tree-cutting team in Indonesia. [indiscernible] was stuck in upper body by a falling tree and recently succumbed to his injuries. Our thoughts are with his family and his colleagues. Our work to make our operations safer and more efficient never ends. 
Turning to our cost performance on Slide 6. Our gold all-in sustaining costs were $835 per ounce, bringing our year-to-date cost to $864 per ounce. This represents a 27% reduction since 2012, about half the improvements we achieved in the third quarter as a result of sustainable cost and efficiency improvements across the portfolio and higher productivity and sales at low-cost operations. We also benefited from favorable oil price and exchange rates and some delayed timing in our capital expenditures. 
Turning to production on Slide 7. We produced more than 1.3 million attributable ounces of gold during the third quarter. This constitutes 16% more than the prior year quarter, and our highest output in the last 7 quarters. New production from CC&V offset about 2/3 of the reductions associated with divestments. We also produced 48,000 tons of copper, mostly as a result of higher grades at Batu Hijau. I'll highlight 4 operation that drove this performance.
At Batu Hijau, third quarter production reflected higher Phase 6 ore grades, which we'll mine through 2017. At Boddington, mine plan and full potential improvements unlock higher grades and increased new utilization and recoveries. Tanami delivered strong production, and on back of higher grade and improved productivity and also mill utilization, which were achieved through full potential. And finally, Twin Creeks, benefited from improved mill grades and the completion of planned stripping campaign. Putting it all together, our operations are doing good work to maximize opportunities and mitigate challenges. 
Turning to Slide 8. In North America, the Turf Vent Shaft remains on schedule to reach commercial production in the fourth quarter, and will be completed below budget. Engineering and mine development also remain on track at Long Canyon, where we continue to expect first production in 2017. You can see the leach pad and other surface facilities in this photo.
The CC&V integration is also progressing, and the operation celebrated 5 million ounces of gold produced last month. Ramp up to full-mill capacity is slightly behind schedule, and we've adjusted our outlook accordingly. We're working out the bugs and the delay is not expected to impact longer-term production. 
Turning to South America. Merian remains on budget and on schedule to begin producing in 2016. Construction is just over 40% complete and we've stockpiled more than 930,000 tons of ore at higher than planned grades. We're also advancing Project Integral, a phased approach to developing Yanacocha's remaining oxide and sulfide deposits, and we'll have initial findings by mid-2016.
In Africa, we're now operating at full capacity on grid power and Ahafo's new generators will be commissioned by year end. We're also advancing our broader power strategy to secure reliable and affordable supply over the long term.
In Indonesia, we expect our export permit to be renewed in near future and continue to work with the government to finalize amendments to our contract at work. In the meantime, we're operating in full capacity and storing concentrate or shipping it Gresik to for processing. In Australia, we've announced that we're moving forward with the Tanami Expansion project. 
Turning to Slide 9. Since 2012, Tanami has more than doubled its gold production, while cutting costs by about 2/3 and significantly improving resource confidence. The Tanami Expansion project builds on this trajectory. It involves constructing a second decline in the underground mine and incremental capacity in the plant to increase profitable production and extend the mine life.
The project is the outcome of a detailed review of options to maximize near-term cash flow and long-term asset value. In the first 5 years of full production, the expansion will increase Tanami's average annual gold production by 80,000 ounces, lower all-in sustaining costs by between 5% and 10% and extend mine life by 3 years. First production is expected in the second half of 2017.
Adding a second decline will also serve as a platform for exploration drilling to support future expansions. As I mentioned last quarter, we see the potential to double current reserves and resources at comparable grades, by expanding the Callie and Auron deposits, and developing new discoveries at Federation and Liberator.
We're excited about this project and what the team has done to optimize it. For an investment of between $100 million and $120 million, the project provides a return of more than 35%, at $1,100 gold and more than 25% at gold prices as low as $900 per ounce. 
With that, I'll hand it over to Laurie for an update on our financial results.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Gary, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to report that Newmont delivered a great quarter with solid financial results. Turning to slide 11. As Gary mentioned, we continue to see cost improvement across the portfolio. Our third quarter gold
componenttext:
Thanks, Gary, and good morning, everyone. I'm pleased to report that Newmont delivered a great quarter with solid financial results. 
Turning to slide 11. As Gary mentioned, we continue to see cost improvement across the portfolio. Our third quarter gold cost applicable to sales per ounce and gold all-in sustaining costs per ounce were 14% and 16% favorable, respectively, to the prior year quarter. With these most recent results, we have maintained our portfolio all-in sustaining costs below $1,000 per ounce for the last 5 quarters running. Gold production was also strong in the quarter and was up 16% from the prior year. Despite a 13% decline in the average realized gold price from a year ago, we continue to generate strong earnings and robust cash flow. 
Turning to slide 12. During the third quarter, revenue was up 16% and we generated $813 million in cash from continuing operations, an increase of more than 148% from the year-ago quarter. Adjusted EBITDA was up 67% from the prior year, due to higher production at Batu Hijau, Boddington, Tanami and Twin Creeks, improved oil prices and exchange rates and ongoing cost and efficiency improvements.
Consolidated free cash flow was $478 million during the third quarter as higher sales volumes and improved cost offset increased development capital spending at Merian and Long Canyon Phase 1. With these most recent results, our year-to-date free cash flow has grown to $941 million, an amount roughly 8x more than what was generated a year ago. We reported adjusted net income of $126 million in the third quarter or $0.23 per share, compared to $249 million or $0.50 per share last year. 
Turning to slide 13, we'll walked through the adjusted net income adjustments, which include a $0.04 per share gain related to discontinued operations, a $0.10 per share gain related to the TMAC deconsolidation. In the past, we fully consolidated TMAC, but upon completion of their IPO, that is no longer required for accounting purposes. Their results will not be included in our line-by-line numbers going forward, and instead will be captured in our equity income line. This gain was on the actual event of deconsolidation and we carved it out for purposes of adjusted net income. It also gave rise to a $0.05 per share gain, resulting from an adjustment to our tax valuation allowances. 
In the quarter, we also recognized a $0.07 per share gain on asset sales, primarily our stake in Valcambi refinery. For adjusted net income purposes, we also carved out of $0.04 per share loss related to impairments and loss provisions, and a $0.03 per share loss is related to restructuring, acquisition costs and other minor items.
After reconciling for these items, we reported adjusted net income of $126 million or $0.23 per share. We're particularly pleased to note that this number includes $0.02 of accretion from the addition of CC&V to our portfolio for just a short 2 months. A similar outcome is seen in adjusted EBITDA of $758 million, up 67% from the prior year. It is adjusted for essentially the same unusual items. 
Now turning to slide 14. A strong balance sheet provides a competitive advantage in a volatile gold price environment, and we continue to execute on capital priorities designed to safeguard our investment-grade ratings. At the end of the third quarter, our balance sheet had roughly $3 billion in cash and cash equivalents. In addition, we had about $400 million in marketable securities and a $3 billion revolver that is essentially undrawn. In total, that's $6.4 billion of liquidity. This and our strong cash flow in 2015 gives us the comfort that we can start and finish our projects without having to take on additional debt to fund them. 
During the third quarter, we repaid $50 million of debt toward the PTNNT revolver. This brings our year-to-date total debt payments $330 million. We expect to pay down further debt later this year and are on track to repay a total of $750 million by year-end. As always, further payments will be made in context of the current business and market environment, but our significant cash balance certainly supports our ability to pay off additional debt. 
Given our existing cash balances and revolver, we have ample flexibility to execute on our capital priorities and are actively monitoring the gold price and the fixed income market to evaluate our options. We also maintained our dividend in light of our strong cash flow and operating performance. As a reminder, we have no significant debt maturities due until 2019, and our current net-debt-to-book capital of 19% is well below the maximum 62.5% covenant on our revolver, which is our only covenant. 
And now, turning to slide 15. We're proud that our net debt-to-EBITDA ratio of roughly 1.1% is among the lowest in the industry and has continued to improve. We have transformed Newmont's balance sheet into one of the strongest in the sector, and our liquidity and cash flow generation separate us from the competition. We have reduced our net debt by 32% from the prior year quarter. And more importantly, we have reduced net debt, while also growing our EBITDA, which significantly improved our financial flexibility. We remain comfortable with our relative level of debt and maturity profile and we will continue to examine ways to reduce the absolute debt level and increase the long-term strength of our business. 
And now, I'll turn the call back over to Gary.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Laurie. I'll shift gears now to look at the future, turning to slide 17. We expect to end 2015 with attributable gold production at the higher end of our guidance range, which is between 4.7 million and 5.1 million ounces, and copper products of b
componenttext:
Thanks, Laurie. I'll shift gears now to look at the future, turning to slide 17. We expect to end 2015 with attributable gold production at the higher end of our guidance range, which is between 4.7 million and 5.1 million ounces, and copper products of between 140,000 and 180,000 tons. The changes we're making to our 2015 guidance are twofold. 
First, we're looking -- we're lowering our outlook for gold all-in sustaining costs 4% to between $880 and $940. This reflects strong performance, particularly in Asia Pacific and Africa, as well as lower exchange rates in favorable power and diesel prices. We expect these costs to rise slightly in the fourth quarter due to higher exploration and advanced project spending, sustaining capital timing and lower grades at Yanacocha and Ahafo.
Second, we lowered our full year outlook for capital expenditure by about 9% to between $1.4 billion and $1.6 billion. This reduction reflects lower sustaining capital expenditures of between $740 million and $780 million or 13% below previous guidance, gained through cost and efficiency improvements at Yanacocha, Boddington, Batu Hijau, Ahafo and Akyem as well as some timing impacts. Our improved outlook also deflects lower development capital, including $50 million in savings at Merian, realized through supply-chain improvements, favorable exchange rates and lower commodity prices. This reduction is partially offset by new development capital for the Tanami Expansion project.
Our project pipeline continues to be one of the strongest in the gold sector. Turning to slide 18. Our projects focus on profitably extending the life of our existing operations or opening perspective new mining districts. Before we reach funding decisions, we scrutinize our approach to each project with a goal to lower initial capital cost, accelerate payback and leverage existing infrastructure. 
Projects that are in the execution phase include the Turf Vent Shaft, which will give us access to be between 100,000 and 150,000 ounces of higher-grade ore per year and support for the expansion at Leeville. Merian, which will deliver 400,000 to 500,000 ounces of gold and all-in sustaining costs of between $650 to $750 per ounce for the first 5 years beginning in 2016. The Cripple Creek & Victor expansion, which includes the new mill, leach pad and recovery plant that will be commissioned in second half of 2016. CC&V will contribute between 350,000 and 400,000 ounces of gold in 2016 and 2017 and is expected to lower Newmont's overall cost profile.
The first phase of Long Canyon, which will add between 100,000 ounces of gold production per year and 150,000 ounces of gold per year at all-in sustaining costs of between $500 and $600 per ounce beginning in 2017. And finally, the Tanami Expansion project, which I touched on earlier. Further up the pipeline, we're advancing the Ahafo mill expansion in Subika underground mine in Ghana. These projects are designed to help offset the impact of lower grades and harder ore. We have deferred the decision to proceed with the Ahafo mill expansion until the second half of next year to coincide with our timing on the Subika underground decision.
We're also progressing the Phase 7 cutback at Batu Hijau, where we are working to secure the stability we need for ongoing investment; Quecher Main, which is part of the oxide expansion effort in Yanacocha; and Northwest Exodus in Nevada, which would extend the current underground operation and add profitable production. 
Turning to exploration on Slide 19. Exploration is one of our core competencies. About 70% of the gold we're mining in 2015 was discovered by Newmont geologists. Our program focuses on maintaining our existing resource base, while preserving options to pursue significant new discoveries. We employ rigorous standards to make sure the highest-quality ounces are added to our reserve base, and we've developed a proprietary geologic risk assessment project to improve our orebody confidence. This map shows prospects in Nevada, Peru, Ghana and Australia that we expect to be in production before 2020, and longer term prospects in the U.S., Ethiopia and the Guiana Shield.
Turning to slide 20, for a closer look at our underground prospects that Exodus in Nevada. Exodus is a high-grade underground orebody that was identified in 2008, with a 300,000-ounce discovery. Through new discoveries at Northwest Exodus in 2011 and Exodus Footwall in 2013, we've grown the resource base to 1.2 million ounces to date, of which 300,000 ounces have been mined. We see the potential to double this figure over the next few years by converting mineral inventory into reserves and resource, and by drilling the remaining half of Exodus' targeted mineralization. 
Turning to slide 21. Northwest Exodus is located several hundred meters from Exodus. We declared a main resource of 700,000 ounces in 2014, and expect to declare first reserves in early 2016. Compared to our initial Exodus discovery, Northwest Exodus is larger, with 50% higher grades, mineralization remains open on the hanging wall.
Turning to slide 22. the Exodus Footwall is our latest high-grade discovery, and is located in different stratigraphy than Exodus and Northwest Exodus. We recently identified mineralization of up to 51 meters at grades of 12.5 grams per ton and the footwall remains open along strike and at depth. We anticipate declaring first resource at Exodus Footwall in early 2016. While we intend to pursue these opportunities, we're also prepared for ongoing market volatility. 
Turning to slide 23. At today's metal prices, we can afford to advance our best projects and exploration projects -- or prospects, fund our dividends and repay debt. This chart gives you an idea of what we might do differently in a prolonged period of lower or higher gold prices. Under significant constraints, we would delay stripping campaigns and sustain capital. We complete our current projects and further reduce overhead and exploration cost. As gold price improves, we will continue to optimize cost in capital, fund our most profitable projects, accelerate debt repayment and increase dividend in line with our policy. Getting our house in order now allows us to deliver superior margins when gold price recovers. 
Turning to slide 24. We're continuing to make good progress toward our goal to become the world's most profitable and reliable gold producer. We will reach that goal by continuing to deliver our strategy to improve our underlying business, by continuously raising our safety, cost and technical performance to strengthen our portfolio by building a longer life, lower-cost asset base and to create shareholder value by generating cash, paying dividends and strengthening our investment grade balance sheet. Thank you for your time. 
I'd like to open the floor to questions now, operator?

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions. I suppose -- you're saying, obviously, the benefits of the tailwinds from the Aussie dollars and oil price are falling. Can you just sort of give us some comments on how would you think about going forward with hedging and woul
componenttext: Just a couple of questions. I suppose -- you're saying, obviously, the benefits of the tailwinds from the Aussie dollars and oil price are falling. Can you just sort of give us some comments on how would you think about going forward with hedging and would you increase your hedging exposure on the cost side?

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Andrew. Historically, we've had foreign exchange hedges in place in Australia and a little bit New Zealand, of course, New Zealand with the sale of Waihi has gone away. In Australia, we liquidated about 2/3 of our position back -- about 2 years ago,
componenttext: Sure, Andrew. Historically, we've had foreign exchange hedges in place in Australia and a little bit New Zealand, of course, New Zealand with the sale of Waihi has gone away. In Australia, we liquidated about 2/3 of our position back -- about 2 years ago, it's been November of 2013. And we're continuing to draw that down, it runs out basically. It's pretty small now. And over the next 2 to 3 years, is gone, but it's very small portion. We don't see ourselves changing our hedge position or increasing it, quite frankly. We've seen a good correlation between gold price and the Aussie dollar, not that, that clearly drives anything, but we don't see any need to make a change in our position on the foreign exchange rate hedging. When it comes to the diesel fuel, we basically do that in Nevada, because of the ability for us to take hedge accounting. And we're not taking a position on where the price will go, it's just we do it in order to try to smooth out what the price swings might be. So we've got basically an evergreen-type hedge book arrangement there that we continue out over a 2 to 2.5 year period to cover that. But we're not taking any strong positions on price there either. [indiscernible].

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it's great. I suppose other one is on Indonesia and on Batu. I mean, it's -- I think in short term, it's fine with the export losses. But sort of booking into sort of [indiscernible] and I know it'd be nice to know if we had a crystal ball. But do you
componenttext: No, it's great. I suppose other one is on Indonesia and on Batu. I mean, it's -- I think in short term, it's fine with the export losses. But sort of booking into sort of [indiscernible] and I know it'd be nice to know if we had a crystal ball. But do you think you'd face -- I mean, is there a time that you need to make a decision on this? Obviously, with the government and more understanding about what's happening with middle prices that you've seen over the last couple of years?

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think the way we're looking at it, we need to clearly get the export permit and we expect that here in the next week or 2 in terms of getting that. So we continue to mine through Phase 6, and that's just been part of the process every 6 months of r
componenttext: Yes, I think the way we're looking at it, we need to clearly get the export permit and we expect that here in the next week or 2 in terms of getting that. So we continue to mine through Phase 6, and that's just been part of the process every 6 months of renewing that. In terms of the contract to work, we do need to get those changes now done. We agreed those changes a little over a year ago with an MoU with the government and just really need to get that finalized and get the certainty of that, as well as get the financing in place. Like we did in the phase 6, get the financing in place to support phase 7. So I would expect -- and the way we're looking at it, we've got over the next year to get that in place and that's the time frame that we're looking at.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to -- following on from you exploration commentary, how are your geologists thinking about reserves that you're in? What sort of gold price do you think you'll be using? And how do you think results will look at presumably lower gold prices?
componenttext: Just wanted to -- following on from you exploration commentary, how are your geologists thinking about reserves that you're in? What sort of gold price do you think you'll be using? And how do you think results will look at presumably lower gold prices?

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we'll give -- thanks for the question, John. We'll give the detailed update on that in February when we do the update on reserves and resources at year-end. But we've given previous sensitivities out there on what it looks like at say $100 lower rese
componenttext: Yes, we'll give -- thanks for the question, John. We'll give the detailed update on that in February when we do the update on reserves and resources at year-end. But we've given previous sensitivities out there on what it looks like at say $100 lower reserve price from -- we're using currently 1,300 for reserves, and at 1,200. Right now, I would expect we'd probably move to 1,200, but I don't expect us to see as big a swing on the reserves as what we had shown in that sensitivity. Really 2 things helping that. One has been how we've gotten our cost down throughout the organization, and that helps make things economic at lower prices. The other piece has been the swing in the Aussie dollar, where would where we would have seen potentially an impact at Boddington. I wouldn't expect that we'd see that, but we'll give the details and have the details on that one when we come out with the reserve and resource numbers and -- at the beginning of this next year.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. And then as a follow up, Merian, you're coming in the low budget with that project, just wondered if you're learning with that process? And maybe the amount of cost of doing things in this current environment is making to think differently
componenttext: That's helpful. And then as a follow up, Merian, you're coming in the low budget with that project, just wondered if you're learning with that process? And maybe the amount of cost of doing things in this current environment is making to think differently about some of the other projects.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Definitely. I think there's been some very interesting approaches and good approaches taken to how equipment is being assembled offsite, prepared and put together offsite, so that it eases the way we can construct it onsite. I used the leach cell or tanks
componenttext: Definitely. I think there's been some very interesting approaches and good approaches taken to how equipment is being assembled offsite, prepared and put together offsite, so that it eases the way we can construct it onsite. I used the leach cell or tanks that we use for the cyanide leach portion are being assembled in sections and then bolted together, rather than having a bunch of welders on and fabricate those onsite, is one simple example of that. But the more we can make modules and import things that way in this particular location, it's worked out well and that could apply in other areas when I think, for instance, Ahafo North. And it's down the road another couple of years, but I can see that applying there as well.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to circle back on the prior questions about Indonesia and Batu. Gary, you mentioned, you expect to get permit in the next week or 2. In a -- an alternate scenario where it doesn't happen, how long can you keep Batu running, though, and have suffi
componenttext: I wanted to circle back on the prior questions about Indonesia and Batu. Gary, you mentioned, you expect to get permit in the next week or 2. In a -- an alternate scenario where it doesn't happen, how long can you keep Batu running, though, and have sufficient on-site storage capacity? And given that -- like Freeport, they do have that export license. Are there alternatives such as Freeport exporting more concentrate and you guys get maybe a greater share of the smelter just to bridge any kind of timing gap?

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Brian, we're not really connected with Freeport on export permit. Theirs is a different condition than ours. We kind of trailed theirs, where they had some issues once they got their permit on currency. We had that addressed along the way, so that's not t
componenttext: Brian, we're not really connected with Freeport on export permit. Theirs is a different condition than ours. We kind of trailed theirs, where they had some issues once they got their permit on currency. We had that addressed along the way, so that's not the issue. Our biggest piece is just working through the final requirements the government has, which is what we went through the last time through this process. We expect -- very confident we'll get that. Failing that, we do have about 3 weeks of capacity left in the concentrate storage barn. And if we want to have that then we'd have to look at curtailing production. But I really don't expect that to happen, given all the things we're doing on the ground and the progress that's being made.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And the second question is just on CC&V, you mentioned a little bit of delay in the mill ramp. Could you provide a little bit more detail? And then second, along those lines, you are keeping your guidance for next year, so maybe like order of magnit
componenttext: Okay. And the second question is just on CC&V, you mentioned a little bit of delay in the mill ramp. Could you provide a little bit more detail? And then second, along those lines, you are keeping your guidance for next year, so maybe like order of magnitude in what you're talking about in terms of weeks or months in terms of slippage when it gets to fall run rate?

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. I'm going to hand over and ask Chris Robison to explain what's going there.
componenttext: Sure. I'm going to hand over and ask Chris Robison to explain what's going there.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the -- Brian, there is a couple of things that -- first off, we're working through some design issues that we're confident that we can solve by taking more time. So the ramp up of the actual equipment has taken a bit longer than we would woul
componenttext: Yes. I think the -- Brian, there is a couple of things that -- first off, we're working through some design issues that we're confident that we can solve by taking more time. So the ramp up of the actual equipment has taken a bit longer than we would would've expected. I think the other aspect of it is around ore blending, making some changes around how we mine and feed the plant that we're addressing to get more throughput and maximize the grade through the plant as it was designed for. And I think the third piece that maybe addresses the question longer term is, we're looking at how to reconfigure that plant with the opportunity to take the concentrate from there, rather than leaching it there and the complexities that, that brings within the plant, taking that concentrate to Nevada and putting it in either our autoclaves at Twin or our roaster it at Carlin, which is an advantage for both CC&V and absolutely the 2 Nevada operations.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then with the design issues, so you're going to handle the concentrate maybe a little bit differently. It's not -- that's not a CapEx fix?
componenttext: Okay. And then with the design issues, so you're going to handle the concentrate maybe a little bit differently. It's not -- that's not a CapEx fix?

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, it's -- if we do the reconfiguration that we're looking at, it's not a significant CapEx issue. It's in -- the issues we're dealing with right now are primarily around the back end of the plant, the filtration of both the tails and the con, and that's
componenttext: No, it's -- if we do the reconfiguration that we're looking at, it's not a significant CapEx issue. It's in -- the issues we're dealing with right now are primarily around the back end of the plant, the filtration of both the tails and the con, and that's where the lower mechanical availability is, its driving the whole plant. But we're confident we can fix that, but also with this reconfiguration takes pressure off that part of the plant.

componenttextpreview: It's good question, John, and we, quite frankly, haven't stopped our drilling there. We continue to do the drilling at both of those sites. Both infill, around, but also looking in the region. So at Long Canyon, we're looking not only around the existing
componenttext: It's good question, John, and we, quite frankly, haven't stopped our drilling there. We continue to do the drilling at both of those sites. Both infill, around, but also looking in the region. So at Long Canyon, we're looking not only around the existing Long Canyon, but looking in that region, in both Utah and Nevada. Merian, we continue to look for additional saprolite ore in the area around Merian as well. So it's not something we've discontinued and it fits within where we continue to look in our brownfield and what we call wingspan areas.

componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Tanya. We have not addressed that yet, so thank you very much for the question. We're still in the process of finalizing the purchase pricing allocation work. I would say as we did the fair value reviews of everything, we've allocated a bit less to the stockpiles than you would have seen AGA do, as we did fair values on every asset. And sometimes it does result in different allocation. And that drove the lower prices. We will give our full '16, '17 update guidance at the Investor Day in December. But I think you can assume that we will come in a little bit lower than what we had originally done, but we want to complete that work before we finish -- before we give that information.

componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tanya. We haven't covered that yet, but good question. It's one that we actually have been working for a number of years with the government as they brought forward new regulations, and then been working with them on modifying them. They actually
componenttext: Thanks, Tanya. We haven't covered that yet, but good question. It's one that we actually have been working for a number of years with the government as they brought forward new regulations, and then been working with them on modifying them. They actually rolled out some regulations that exceed by almost 1,000 times what requirements are in most other countries around the world, so trying to get the regulations back to something that's actually physically achievable on the ground. We've been making an investment in a water treatment plant there since earlier this year that is scheduled to be completed to be earlier next year. That would put us on track to meet what we would expect to be final regulations. We're still working through that process with the government.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And has it been very cordial in terms of exceeding 1,000 times the required regulations in other jurisdictions, are they pretty amenable to acknowledging that this might be not achievable?

componenttext: Yes. No, Gary, I'd probably just echo what you said that we're still confident that we can achieve those sort of improvements in the mine as we work through it. And I think, as you said, it's early days. Our mine planning folks and technical folks continue to look at it, but we're optimistic that we can do that. I think the other piece of it is, while we talk about the mill, the new value leach is going very well. Our team is very confident that we can bring that in on time or a bit ahead of schedule and comfortable with cost there. So while the focus a bit on the mill, the heart of the operation is the valley leach, and that's going very well, early stage with our folks coming on and taking that over.

headline: Newmont Mining Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, again, for joining our third quarter earnings call this morning. Our team continues to drive stronger performance across the portfolio and the sector, and we're not resting on our laurels. Our goal is to continue improving safety and efficiency at
componenttext: Thanks, again, for joining our third quarter earnings call this morning. Our team continues to drive stronger performance across the portfolio and the sector, and we're not resting on our laurels. Our goal is to continue improving safety and efficiency at our operations and to continue building a longer-life, lower-cost portfolio. Ultimately, we're working to create the value we need to fund profitable growth, pay down debt, and most importantly, generate cash for our shareholders. Thanks, again, and have a safe day.
